(When "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a=b=2"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".) "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned}
n^3&=a^2+b^2 \\
&=(a+b)^2-2ab \\
ab&=\frac{n^4-n^3}{2} \\
a+b&=n^2 \end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"We can get that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a, b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" are the roots of "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"x^2-n^2x+\frac{n^4-n^3}{2}=0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". The discriminant of quadratic eqn above must bigger or equal to "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"0"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Hence
"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned}
n^4-2(n^4-n^3)\geq 0 \\
n^3(n-2) \leq 0 \\
0\leq n \leq 2 \end{aligned}"}],"attrs":{"inline":false}},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\begin{aligned} \{ t(n) \} & = \underbrace{ {\color{#D61F06}\cancel 1}, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 7, {\color{#D61F06}\cancel 8}, 9, 10, \cdots {\color{#D61F06}\cancel {k^3}}, k^3+1}_{k^3+1-k \text{ terms}} \\ \implies n & = k^3 - k + 1 \\ t(k^3-k+1) & = k^3 + 1 \end{aligned} "}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Now the largest perfect cube smaller than 2038 is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\lfloor \sqrt[3] {2038}\rfloor =12"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":". Then, we have:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Considering the first 3 cicrcles, You can find out that the distance from the vertex of the angle to the epcenter of the first circle is 2 (use metric relations in a semi equilateral triangle). Moving on the next circle, using the same method you can figure out that the radius of this circle is 3, and then the next one is 9.

                                        "},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Detailed Explanation:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Starting with the first circle, it can be broken up into 30-60-90 right triangles where the 30 degree angle is at the vertex of the angle, the right angle is where the circle is tangent to the angle, and the 60 degree angle is at the center.  From there, it can be determined (using the rules of 30-60-90 triangles) that the gap between the first circle and the vertex has a length of 1 and it is known that the circle has a diameter of 2, making the distance to the second circle 3.  This can also be split into a 30-60-90 triangle.  Calling the radius of the second circle "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r_{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we know the length of this triangle's smaller leg is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r_{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and the hypotenuse is 3+"},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r_{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  Using the rules of 30-60-90 triangles, the radius of circle two is 3. This method can be continued and generalized into (using the fact of 30-60-90 triangles that the hypotenuse is twice the shorter leg)(where "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r_{n}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the radius of the nth circle and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is the total distance of the hypotenuse tangent to that circle):"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"\frac{r_{n}}{1}=\frac{r_{n}+d}{2}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2{r_{n}}={r_{n}}+d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{r_{n}}=d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Which means the radius of some circle is the distance of the tangent hypotenuse to it.  To get the tangent hypotenuse to the next triangle (which we now know is also that triangle's radius) we add together the diameter of the circle before it and all the distance before that, or:"}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{r_{n}}=2{r_{n-1}}+d"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{r_{n}}=2{r_{n-1}}+{r_{n-1}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{r_{n}}=3{r_{n-1}}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"So the radius of circle "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" is three times "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n-1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  Using our knowledge that "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r_{1}=1"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" and "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"r_{2}=3"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", we can convert this into explicit form that "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"{r_{n}}=3^{n-1}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"Plugging in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"n=2018"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" gets "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^{2017}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  The only way this could maximize b more in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a^b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" while keeping it an integer would be "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"2^{something}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":".  Since "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3^{2017}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" obviously only has factors of 3, this cannot be converted while keeping "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" an integer.  Since the question is asking for "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a+b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" in "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"a^b"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":", the answer is "},{"type":"katex","content":[{"type":"text","text":"3+2017=\fbox{2020}"}],"attrs":{"inline":true}},{"type":"text","text":" "}]},{"type":"text","text":"

"},{"type":"paragraph","content":[{"type":"text","text":"I also added two more equation to verify my assumption that there is always the same factor X (just to be sure)"}]},{"type":"text","text":"
